newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu attends funeral for slain settlers.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu attends funeral for slain settlers.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and cabinet members attended the funeral on Thursday of a Jewish settler and her 12-year-old son killed in an Arab guerrilla attack.

Their presence in a crowd of thousands was a show of government solidarity with the more than 130,000-strong settler community at odds with Netanyahu over his talks with the PLO on Israeli troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.

Etta Tzur and her son Ephraim were killed when gunmen shot at their family car near the self-ruled town of Ramallah in the West Bank on Wednesday. Her husband and four other children were wounded. Israel said the guerrillas escaped into Ramallah.
Israel blamed the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, an opponent of its peace deals with the PLO, for the attack. The PFLP declined to comment on the allegation.
Maher al-Taher, a spokesman for the group, said in Damascus that Palestinians were duty-bound to attack Jewish settlers.
A settler leader urged the government to respond to the incident by taking a "Zionist decision" and settling more Jews in areas captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war.
"For any Jewish blood spilled, 1,000 Jewish families will come here to live," Pinhas Wallerstein, head of the Council of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, told Israel Radio.
Since taking office in June, the right-wing Netanyahu government has given the go-ahead for the construction of thousands of homes in existing settlements but has yet to establish any new outposts.

Palestinian President Yasser Arafat, asked by reporters in Gaza to comment on the killings, kept silent. A PLO official said the Palestinian Authority, which runs self-rule in parts of the West Bank and Gaza, condemned the attack.
At the graveside, National Infrastructure Minister Ariel Sharon, a champion of Jewish settlement, sniped at the Israel-PLO peace accords that set up a Palestinian police force overseen by Arafat.

"The murderers continue to go about their business. The Oslo (peace) accords that put the question of protection of Israeli citizens in the hands of a war criminal by any law continue to cause bloodshed," Sharon said.

In Gaza, Palestinian Justice Minister Freih Abu Medeen saw the shooting in a different context, telling reporters it played into the hands of Netanyahu by giving him ammunition to postpone further a Hebron deal.

"Anything that will delay and kill our dream, we condemn," Medeen said. "Israel needs these incidents. Israel needs these attacks. Israel will find a cover for its delays...This is a gift for Mr Netanyahu."
Israel lashed out at the Palestinian Authority and closed off Ramallah after the attack.
"I think the Authority should understand there is no point in peace talks or agreements if they do not result in security," Finance Minister Dan Meridor told Army Radio.
"This demand has been conveyed to them very sharply and clearly and they must take action," Meridor said.
Netanyahu gave no indication the killing would affect talks with the PLO on Hebron, where some 400 Jewish settlers live or study amid 100,000 Palestinians.
